title: Remains of Bonfire Smolder on Main Shopping Street in Hong Kong
text:
Cardboard and other rubbish from a bonfire started as part of ongoing protests in Hong Kong smoldered on the night of September 6 in the Mong Kok area of the city.

A livestream video of the fire burning was shared on Twitter by Hong Kong Hermit, who subsequently shared a video of the bonfire remains smoldering.

In the video of the smoldering remains, cars can be seen driving over the charred garbage near the intersection of Nathan Road and Argyle Street in Hong Kong.

Protestors later gathered at the Yau Ma Tei MTR subway station, where they vandalized signage, local media reported.

The protests on September 6 occurred days after Carrie Lam, Hong Kong’s Chief Executive, announced full withdrawal of her controversial extradition bill, which originally sparked the protests. The bill would have allowed the extradition of criminal suspects to mainland China for trial.

The protest movement has since called for more democratic representation and an inquiry into the use of force by police. Credit: Hong Kong Hermit via Storyful
